newsitem.title: JORDAN: Hamas says senior member arrested in Jordan.
newsitem.headline: Hamas says senior member arrested in Jordan.

text.p: The Islamic movement Hamas said on Wednesday Jordanian authorities had arrested one of its senior members in a crackdown aimed at weakening its influence in the kingdom and placating Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
A Hamas official said eight other men, including a newspaper editor, a university teacher, a student and the head of a hospital nursing department, had been detained in the last week.
"These arrests have taken place suddenly and at Jordan's initiative," a senior Hamas official who asked not to be named told Reuters.

"The aim of the arrests is to please the government of Benjamin Netanyahu by striking at the political structure of the Hamas movement which has been based in Jordan for a number of years, in agreement with the previous government," he said.
Jordanian officials were not immediately available for comment.

The Hamas source said the wave of arrests began one week ago. The latest detainee was Abdel-Aziz al-Amri, described as a Hamas politburo member and general manager of the London based Islamist magazine Moslem Palestine.
He was arrested in Amman on Wednesday, the source said.
Last week Jordan's Islamic parliamentary party said intelligence services had detained and tortured a Hamas supporter for two weeks.
Jordan denies its security forces torture detainees.
It signed a peace treaty two years ago with Israel and has come under pressure from both the Jewish state and Palestinian authorities to shut down any Hamas activity on its territory.

Hamas, an offshoot of the Moslem Brotherhood Movement, is a social and religious organisation with branches across the West Bank and Gaza Strip. A militant Hamas cell carried out a wave of suicide attacks in Israel this year killing dozens of people.
The Hamas source said the group had reached agreement with previous Jordanian governments that its presence in Jordan would be limited to political and promotional activities.
Jordan says Hamas has no formal legal presence in the country. But it says the government is unable to prevent Jordanian citizens expressing strong opposition to Israel.
